subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... Okay, so basically they can be represented by letters. I just wanted to clarify this. ... Yes, of course! But that just means that in Spanish [d] and [D]
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>
>
> paulhtremblay scripsit:
>
> > > Your trouble stems from the fact that phonemes cannot be identified
> > > either with sounds or with written letters, but constitute a third,
> > > separate level.
> >
> > Why can't they be represented with written letters?
>
> By "written letters" I meant the letters used in traditional orthography.
> In works on English, the phonemes can be and are represented by letters,
> sometimes corresponding to the IPA and sometimes not; these letters
> are traditionally written between slashes to distinguish them from IPA
> letters representing sounds, which are written between square brackets,
> as well as from words in TO, which are in italics, underlined, or (in
> email) in quotation marks or angle brackets.

Okay, so basically they can be represented by letters. I just wanted to
clarify this.

>
> > And on the same note, why can't they be represented by sounds?
>
> A phoneme doesn't correspond with a sound, but is an abstract entity
> that contrasts with other abstract entities. IPA is used to write
> sounds, and can be adapted to represent phonemes, but it's important to
> remember that this is a specialized use. We may write /d/ for the Spanish
> phoneme corresponding to "d" in Spanish orthography, but the sounds this
> represents vary from [d] to [D] (the voiced interdental fricative) to
> zero, depending on their context. Indeed, one can say that [D] is the
> basic sound and the other two are specialized cases, but by convention
> we write the phoneme as /d/, though in theory /D/ would be just as good.
>
> But the important point is that [d] and [D] do not contrast in Spanish:
> they are part of the same abstract entity. In English, they definitely do
> contrast: "day" vs. "they", "breathe" vs. "breed", "mother" vs. "mudder".

Yes, of course! But that just means that in Spanish [d] and [D] are
allophones and in English they are phonemes.

Paul
